trans-unit.source: Custom SaaS connector ASP.NET API app in Azure App Service
trans-unit.target: Custom SaaS connector ASP.NET API app in Azure App Service

trans-unit.source: Learn how to write code that connects to a SaaS platform from an API app and how to call the API app from a .NET client.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to write code that connects to a SaaS platform from an API app and how to call the API app from a .NET client.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial shows how to code and configure an <linkText>API app</linkText><title></title> that connects to a <linkText>Software-as-a-Service (SaaS) platform</linkText><title></title> using the <linkText>App Service API app SDK for .NET</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial shows how to code and configure an <linkText>API app</linkText><title></title> that connects to a <linkText>Software-as-a-Service (SaaS) platform</linkText><title></title> using the <linkText>App Service API app SDK for .NET</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The tutorial also shows how to call the API app from a .NET client by using the <linkText>App Service SDK for .NET</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: The tutorial also shows how to call the API app from a .NET client by using the <linkText>App Service SDK for .NET</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: At the end of the tutorial you'll have a .NET console app client that calls a .NET API app running in Azure App Service.
trans-unit.target: At the end of the tutorial you'll have a .NET console app client that calls a .NET API app running in Azure App Service.

trans-unit.source: The API app calls the Dropbox API and returns a list of files and folders in the user's Dropbox account.
trans-unit.target: The API app calls the Dropbox API and returns a list of files and folders in the user's Dropbox account.

trans-unit.source: As an alternative to writing code that calls a SaaS API directly from a custom API app, you can call a prepackaged <linkText>connector API app</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: As an alternative to writing code that calls a SaaS API directly from a custom API app, you can call a prepackaged <linkText>connector API app</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: For information about how to do that, see <linkText>Deploy and configure a SaaS connector API app</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For information about how to do that, see <linkText>Deploy and configure a SaaS connector API app</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The tutorial walks you through the following steps:
trans-unit.target: The tutorial walks you through the following steps:

trans-unit.source: Create an API app project in Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: Create an API app project in Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: Configure the apiapp.json file to enable the API app to connect to the Dropbox service.
trans-unit.target: Configure the apiapp.json file to enable the API app to connect to the Dropbox service.

trans-unit.source: Add code that calls Dropbox and returns the results.
trans-unit.target: Add code that calls Dropbox and returns the results.

trans-unit.source: Create a new API app in Azure.
trans-unit.target: Create a new API app in Azure.

trans-unit.source: Deploy the project to the API app.
trans-unit.target: Deploy the project to the API app.

trans-unit.source: Configure the API app.
trans-unit.target: Configure the API app.

trans-unit.source: Configure the gateway.
trans-unit.target: Configure the gateway.

trans-unit.source: Create a test client.
trans-unit.target: Create a test client.

trans-unit.source: Run the test client.
trans-unit.target: Run the test client.

trans-unit.source: The tutorial makes these assumptions:
trans-unit.target: The tutorial makes these assumptions:

trans-unit.source: You have completed the <linkText>Create an API app</linkText><title></title> and <linkText>Deploy an API app</linkText><title></title> tutorials.
trans-unit.target: You have completed the <linkText>Create an API app</linkText><title></title> and <linkText>Deploy an API app</linkText><title></title> tutorials.

trans-unit.source: You have a basic understanding of the Azure App Service gateway architecture for authentication, as presented in <linkText>Authentication for API apps and mobile apps</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: You have a basic understanding of the Azure App Service gateway architecture for authentication, as presented in <linkText>Authentication for API apps and mobile apps</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: You know how to work with API apps in the Azure preview portal, as explained in <linkText>How to navigate to API app and gateway blades</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: You know how to work with API apps in the Azure preview portal, as explained in <linkText>How to navigate to API app and gateway blades</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: When the instructions direct you to enter a name for the project, enter SimpleDropbox.
trans-unit.target: When the instructions direct you to enter a name for the project, enter SimpleDropbox.

trans-unit.source: For an API app to make outgoing calls to a SaaS platform, the SaaS platform has to be specified in the apiapp.json file.
trans-unit.target: For an API app to make outgoing calls to a SaaS platform, the SaaS platform has to be specified in the apiapp.json file.

trans-unit.source: Open the apiapp.json file and add an authentication property as shown here (you'll also have to add a comma after the preceding property):
trans-unit.target: Open the apiapp.json file and add an authentication property as shown here (you'll also have to add a comma after the preceding property):

trans-unit.source: The complete apiapp.json file will resemble this example:
trans-unit.target: The complete apiapp.json file will resemble this example:

trans-unit.source: Save the file.
trans-unit.target: Save the file.

trans-unit.source: Setting the authentication property has a couple effects:
trans-unit.target: Setting the authentication property has a couple effects:

trans-unit.source: It causes the portal to display UI in the API app blade that enables you to enter the SaaS platform's client ID and client secret values.
trans-unit.target: It causes the portal to display UI in the API app blade that enables you to enter the SaaS platform's client ID and client secret values.

trans-unit.source: It enables the API app to retrieve the SaaS provider's access token from the gateway for use when calling the SaaS provider's API.
trans-unit.target: It enables the API app to retrieve the SaaS provider's access token from the gateway for use when calling the SaaS provider's API.

trans-unit.source: The authentication property is an array, but this preview release doesn't support specifying multiple providers.
trans-unit.target: The authentication property is an array, but this preview release doesn't support specifying multiple providers.

trans-unit.source: For a list of the supported platforms, see <linkText>Getting user consent to access other SaaS platforms</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For a list of the supported platforms, see <linkText>Getting user consent to access other SaaS platforms</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: You can also specify scopes, as in this example:
trans-unit.target: You can also specify scopes, as in this example:

trans-unit.source: Available scopes are defined by each SaaS provider and can be found in the provider's developer portal.
trans-unit.target: Available scopes are defined by each SaaS provider and can be found in the provider's developer portal.

trans-unit.source: Install the <linkText>DropboxRestAPI</linkText><title></title> NuGet package in the SimpleDropbox project.
trans-unit.target: Install the <linkText>DropboxRestAPI</linkText><title></title> NuGet package in the SimpleDropbox project.

trans-unit.source: From the Tools menu, click NuGet Package Manager > Package Manager Console.
trans-unit.target: From the Tools menu, click NuGet Package Manager > Package Manager Console.

trans-unit.source: In the Package Manager Console window, enter this command:
trans-unit.target: In the Package Manager Console window, enter this command:

trans-unit.source: Open Controllers\ValuesController.cs and replace all of the code in the file with the following code.
trans-unit.target: Open Controllers\ValuesController.cs and replace all of the code in the file with the following code.

trans-unit.source: Before the client calls this method, the user has logged in to Dropbox and granted consent for the API app to access the user's Dropbox account.
trans-unit.target: Before the client calls this method, the user has logged in to Dropbox and granted consent for the API app to access the user's Dropbox account.

trans-unit.source: Dropbox acknowledges that consent by providing an access token to the App Service gateway.
trans-unit.target: Dropbox acknowledges that consent by providing an access token to the App Service gateway.

trans-unit.source: This code retrieves the token from the gateway and includes it in a call to the Dropbox API, as shown in steps 6 and 7 in the diagram below.
trans-unit.target: This code retrieves the token from the gateway and includes it in a call to the Dropbox API, as shown in steps 6 and 7 in the diagram below.

trans-unit.source: Build the project.
trans-unit.target: Build the project.

trans-unit.source: In this section you use the Visual Studio Publish Web wizard to create an API app in Azure.
trans-unit.target: In this section you use the Visual Studio Publish Web wizard to create an API app in Azure.

trans-unit.source: Where the instructions direct you to enter a name for the API app, enter SimpleDropbox.
trans-unit.target: Where the instructions direct you to enter a name for the API app, enter SimpleDropbox.

trans-unit.source: You use the same Publish Web wizard to deploy your code to the new API app.
trans-unit.target: You use the same Publish Web wizard to deploy your code to the new API app.

trans-unit.source: For Azure App Service to allow authenticated outgoing calls from the API app, the API app must also require that incoming calls come from authenticated users.
trans-unit.target: For Azure App Service to allow authenticated outgoing calls from the API app, the API app must also require that incoming calls come from authenticated users.

trans-unit.source: This is not a general OAuth 2.0 requirement but is a requirement of the App Service gateway architecture as it is currently implemented.
trans-unit.target: This is not a general OAuth 2.0 requirement but is a requirement of the App Service gateway architecture as it is currently implemented.

trans-unit.source: The screenshots in this section show a ContactsList API app, but the process is the same for the SimpleDropbox API app that you're creating in this tutorial.
trans-unit.target: The screenshots in this section show a ContactsList API app, but the process is the same for the SimpleDropbox API app that you're creating in this tutorial.

trans-unit.source: To enable your API app to call the Dropbox API, you have to exchange settings between your API app and a Dropbox app that you create on the Dropbox developer site.
trans-unit.target: To enable your API app to call the Dropbox API, you have to exchange settings between your API app and a Dropbox app that you create on the Dropbox developer site.

trans-unit.source: The following steps refer to a Dropbox connector API app, but the procedures and UI are the same for the SimpleDropbox API app that you're creating in this tutorial.
trans-unit.target: The following steps refer to a Dropbox connector API app, but the procedures and UI are the same for the SimpleDropbox API app that you're creating in this tutorial.

trans-unit.source: Note: If you don't see fields for the Dropbox client ID and client secret on the SimpleDropbox API app's Authentication blade as shown in the screenshot, make sure that you restarted the gateway as directed after deploying the API app project to the API app.
trans-unit.target: Note: If you don't see fields for the Dropbox client ID and client secret on the SimpleDropbox API app's Authentication blade as shown in the screenshot, make sure that you restarted the gateway as directed after deploying the API app project to the API app.

trans-unit.source: The "dropbox" value in the authentication property of the apiapp.json file that you deployed earlier is what triggers the portal to display these fields.
trans-unit.target: The "dropbox" value in the authentication property of the apiapp.json file that you deployed earlier is what triggers the portal to display these fields.

trans-unit.source: In this section you create a console app project that uses client code generated by Visual Studio to call the SimpleDropbox API app.
trans-unit.target: In this section you create a console app project that uses client code generated by Visual Studio to call the SimpleDropbox API app.

trans-unit.source: The console app instantiates a Windows Forms browser control to handle user interaction with the gateway and Dropbox login web pages.
trans-unit.target: The console app instantiates a Windows Forms browser control to handle user interaction with the gateway and Dropbox login web pages.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, create a console application project and name it SimpleDropboxTest.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, create a console application project and name it SimpleDropboxTest.

trans-unit.source: Set a reference to System.Windows.Forms.
trans-unit.target: Set a reference to System.Windows.Forms.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, right-click References, then click Add Reference.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, right-click References, then click Add Reference.

trans-unit.source: Select the check box at the left of System.Windows.Forms, and then click OK.
trans-unit.target: Select the check box at the left of System.Windows.Forms, and then click OK.

trans-unit.source: The console application will use the Windows Forms assembly to instantiate a browser control when it needs to enable the user to log in to the gateway and to Dropbox.
trans-unit.target: The console application will use the Windows Forms assembly to instantiate a browser control when it needs to enable the user to log in to the gateway and to Dropbox.

trans-unit.source: The screenshots in this section show a ContactsList project and API app, but for this tutorial select the SimpleDropboxTest project and SimpleDropbox API app.
trans-unit.target: The screenshots in this section show a ContactsList project and API app, but for this tutorial select the SimpleDropboxTest project and SimpleDropbox API app.

trans-unit.source: Open Program.cs and replace the code in it with the following code.
trans-unit.target: Open Program.cs and replace the code in it with the following code.

trans-unit.source: Replace {gateway url} with the actual URL of your gateway.
trans-unit.target: Replace {gateway url} with the actual URL of your gateway.

trans-unit.source: You can get the gateway URL from the gateway blade in the portal:
trans-unit.target: You can get the gateway URL from the gateway blade in the portal:

trans-unit.source: Important: Make sure the gateway URL begins with https://, not http://.
trans-unit.target: Important: Make sure the gateway URL begins with https://, not http://.

trans-unit.source: If you copy http:// from the portal, you have to change it to https:// when you paste it in the code.
trans-unit.target: If you copy http:// from the portal, you have to change it to https:// when you paste it in the code.

trans-unit.source: This console application is designed to use a minimum amount of code to illustrate the steps that a client app has to go through.
trans-unit.target: This console application is designed to use a minimum amount of code to illustrate the steps that a client app has to go through.

trans-unit.source: A production application would not typically be a console application and would implement error handling and logging.
trans-unit.target: A production application would not typically be a console application and would implement error handling and logging.

trans-unit.source: Here's an overview of what the code is doing:
trans-unit.target: Here's an overview of what the code is doing:

trans-unit.source: Opens a browser to the gateway login URL for the configured identity provider, in this case Azure Active Directory.
trans-unit.target: Opens a browser to the gateway login URL for the configured identity provider, in this case Azure Active Directory.

trans-unit.source: Handles expected response URL after user logs in: extract user ID and Zumo token, provide them to App Service client object.
trans-unit.target: Handles expected response URL after user logs in: extract user ID and Zumo token, provide them to App Service client object.

trans-unit.source: Uses App Service client object to retrieve a gateway URL that will redirect to the Dropbox link for login and consent.
trans-unit.target: Uses App Service client object to retrieve a gateway URL that will redirect to the Dropbox link for login and consent.

trans-unit.source: Step 1 in the diagram.
trans-unit.target: Step 1 in the diagram.

trans-unit.source: Opens a browser to the gateway consent URL.
trans-unit.target: Opens a browser to the gateway consent URL.

trans-unit.source: Browser gets redirected to Dropbox login and consent link.
trans-unit.target: Browser gets redirected to Dropbox login and consent link.

trans-unit.source: Step 2 in the diagram.
trans-unit.target: Step 2 in the diagram.

trans-unit.source: Closes browser after user logs and gives consent at Dropbox.com.
trans-unit.target: Closes browser after user logs and gives consent at Dropbox.com.

trans-unit.source: Step 3 in the diagram.
trans-unit.target: Step 3 in the diagram.

trans-unit.source: Calls the API app.
trans-unit.target: Calls the API app.

trans-unit.source: Step 5 in the diagram.
trans-unit.target: Step 5 in the diagram.

trans-unit.source: (Step 4 happens behind the scenes between Dropbox.com and the gateway, steps 6 and 7 are done from the API app, not the client.)
trans-unit.target: (Step 4 happens behind the scenes between Dropbox.com and the gateway, steps 6 and 7 are done from the API app, not the client.)

trans-unit.source: Additional notes:
trans-unit.target: Additional notes:

trans-unit.source: The STAThread attribute on the Main method is required by the web browser control and is not related to setting up for or calling the API app.
trans-unit.target: The STAThread attribute on the Main method is required by the web browser control and is not related to setting up for or calling the API app.

trans-unit.source: The gateway login URL shown ends in /aad for Azure Active Directory.
trans-unit.target: The gateway login URL shown ends in /aad for Azure Active Directory.

trans-unit.source: Here are the values to use for the other providers:
trans-unit.target: Here are the values to use for the other providers:

trans-unit.source: "microsoftaccount"
trans-unit.target: "microsoftaccount"

trans-unit.source: "facebook"
trans-unit.target: "facebook"

trans-unit.source: "twitter"
trans-unit.target: "twitter"

trans-unit.source: "google"
trans-unit.target: "google"

trans-unit.source: The second parameter for the GetConsentLinkAsync() method is the callback URL that the consent server redirects to after the user logs in to Dropbox and gives consent to access the user's account.
trans-unit.target: The second parameter for the GetConsentLinkAsync() method is the callback URL that the consent server redirects to after the user logs in to Dropbox and gives consent to access the user's account.

trans-unit.source: For this parameter you would normally specify the next web page that the user should go to in the client application.
trans-unit.target: For this parameter you would normally specify the next web page that the user should go to in the client application.

trans-unit.source: Since this demo code is in a console app, there is no application page to go to, and the code specifies the gateway URL just as a convenient landing page.
trans-unit.target: Since this demo code is in a console app, there is no application page to go to, and the code specifies the gateway URL just as a convenient landing page.

trans-unit.source: The client application should verify that it gets redirected to this URL and that there is no error message.
trans-unit.target: The client application should verify that it gets redirected to this URL and that there is no error message.

trans-unit.source: If the login/consent process fails, the redirect URL may contain an error message in the querystring.
trans-unit.target: If the login/consent process fails, the redirect URL may contain an error message in the querystring.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see the <linkText>Troubleshooting</linkText><title></title> section.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see the <linkText>Troubleshooting</linkText><title></title> section.

trans-unit.source: Run the SimpleDropboxTest console application.
trans-unit.target: Run the SimpleDropboxTest console application.

trans-unit.source: In the first logon page, sign in using your Azure Active Directory credentials (or credentials for another identity provider such as Google or Twitter if that's what you configured in the gateway).
trans-unit.target: In the first logon page, sign in using your Azure Active Directory credentials (or credentials for another identity provider such as Google or Twitter if that's what you configured in the gateway).

trans-unit.source: In the Dropbox.com login page, sign in using your Dropbox credentials.
trans-unit.target: In the Dropbox.com login page, sign in using your Dropbox credentials.

trans-unit.source: In the Dropbox consent page, give the application permission to access your data.
trans-unit.target: In the Dropbox consent page, give the application permission to access your data.

trans-unit.source: The console app then calls the API app and it returns a list of the files in your Dropbox account.
trans-unit.target: The console app then calls the API app and it returns a list of the files in your Dropbox account.

trans-unit.source: This section contains the following topics:
trans-unit.target: This section contains the following topics:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>HTTP Error 405 after gateway login</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>HTTP Error 405 after gateway login</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>HTTP Error 400 instead of Dropbox login page</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>HTTP Error 400 instead of Dropbox login page</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>HTTP Error 403 when calling the API app</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>HTTP Error 403 when calling the API app</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: If you get HTTP Error 405 when the code calls GetConsentLinkAsync, verify that you used https://, not http:// for the gateway URL.
trans-unit.target: If you get HTTP Error 405 when the code calls GetConsentLinkAsync, verify that you used https://, not http:// for the gateway URL.

trans-unit.source: The 405 method not allowed error is received because the client attempts to make a non-SSL HTTP POST request, the gateway redirects to https://, and the redirect causes a GET request.
trans-unit.target: The 405 method not allowed error is received because the client attempts to make a non-SSL HTTP POST request, the gateway redirects to https://, and the redirect causes a GET request.

trans-unit.source: The URL for retrieving a consent link only accepts POST requests.
trans-unit.target: The URL for retrieving a consent link only accepts POST requests.

trans-unit.source: Make sure that you have the correct client ID in the API app's Authentication blade, and make sure there are no leading or trailing spaces.
trans-unit.target: Make sure that you have the correct client ID in the API app's Authentication blade, and make sure there are no leading or trailing spaces.

trans-unit.source: Make sure that the Access Level of the API app is set to Public (authenticated), not Internal.
trans-unit.target: Make sure that the Access Level of the API app is set to Public (authenticated), not Internal.

trans-unit.source: Make sure that you have the correct client secret in the API app's Authentication blade, and make sure there are no leading or trailing spaces.
trans-unit.target: Make sure that you have the correct client secret in the API app's Authentication blade, and make sure there are no leading or trailing spaces.

trans-unit.source: The redirect URL after Dropbox login may look like this example:
trans-unit.target: The redirect URL after Dropbox login may look like this example:

trans-unit.source: If you remove the %3d%3d from the end of the error querystring value, this is a valid base64 encoded string.
trans-unit.target: If you remove the %3d%3d from the end of the error querystring value, this is a valid base64 encoded string.

trans-unit.source: Decode the string to get the error message:
trans-unit.target: Decode the string to get the error message:

trans-unit.source: You've seen how to code and configure an API app that connects to a SaaS platform.
trans-unit.target: You've seen how to code and configure an API app that connects to a SaaS platform.

trans-unit.source: For links to other tutorials about how to handle authentication in API apps, see <linkText>Authentication for API apps and mobile apps - Next steps</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For links to other tutorials about how to handle authentication in API apps, see <linkText>Authentication for API apps and mobile apps - Next steps</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.target: https://portal.azure.com/
